market is changing considerably from the
1970s to the 2000s relational databases
reign supreme however in the 2000s as
the internet grew people started to hit

resulted in Amazon developing the dynamo
technology and an associated paper that

development of DynamoDB in 2012 we have
seen a number of other new databases
released around this time such as
MongoDB Riak
Cassandra and CouchDB this means that
there is far more choices in the
database market today than there has
ever been before now let's take a look
at a traditional application and
database architecture still in use today
especially in the enterprise market you
have a client tier accessing an
application or web tier then the
accesses to the relational database that
database is used for all workloads and
all types of data whether it is simple
key value access complex queries or even
heavy query analytics that require full
tablespoons the one relational database
is expected to perform all these tasks
effectively over the years as new types
of workloads and data have evolved the
relational database has evolved with
these demands to be the Swiss Army knife
of database but is it trying to do too
much when deploying applications in the
cloud we believe that you should choose
the best database or datastore for the
workload rather than try to expect one
monolithic database to do it all if you
have a lot of read requests on a set of
data then it is more suited to be placed
in a cache simple key value data
like checking the status of a package
delivery can be pushed into a no sequel
database analytics can be moved to a
dedicated data warehouse logging in the
database is something that we see quite
a lot of but it can take up more space
than the core application data over time
so it's best to move it out of the
database searching of data should be
allocated to a database that is
specialized in this task such as elastic
search there is still a core
responsibility for transactional systems
for the relational database
especially when complex queries are
needed with traditional relationships
relationships and joints when building
your applications you should look at the
characteristics of your application
requirements to select the right
database if you need referential
integrity integrity with strong
consistency for your transactions then a
relational database is still the best
database for the job if you just need
simple key value based queries that
operate very fast and have a very high
throughput then a no sequel database
like Amazon DynamoDB will be a good fit
documents such as those represented by
JSON are now a common storage
requirement and if you need to index and

an interconnected world you may find

relationships between people to help

we support Redis and memcache to finally

Hardware and storage installing

thanks for watching the demo DynamoDB is
a managed no sequel database with low
latency and highly durable storage it's
designed for Tier one applications
it offers massive and seamless
scalability with some customers writing
in excess of a million writes per second
to a single table DynamoDB offers an
amazing feature of providing consistent
single-digit millisecond latency at any
scale even when scaling size or
throughput requirements the storage is
located in three facilities in all
regions even those with to public Ozzy's
to provide high availability and
durability it's easy to use with simple
api's to get and set information it
supports both key value and document
models and there are no table size or
throughput limits some of the popular
use cases for DynamoDB are EdTech IOT
gaming mobile web applications a
consistent use case across many
different industries is user profile and
login management often companies will
hold a large promotion or event that
requires many users to log in all at the
same time for example a gaming company
could send out a notification telling
users to play the game now and receive a
gem or a telco could launch the latest
iPhone at a specific time each of these
situations will create a logon storm
that relational databases would struggle
to deal with dynamodb is able to scale
up for the promotion and then back down
again afterwards so you only pay for the
throughput that you need when you need
it
the dynamodb service has been around
since 2012 so if you have looked at it a
while ago you might not be aware of
the fantastic new features added over
the last year or so in February last
year we introduced the time to live or
plan to live or TTL feature this allows
you to tell dynamodb to delete data
after a specified period of time and
makes it much easier to manage
high-throughput data that you only need
for a short while in april last year we
introduced V PC endpoints removing the
need for your DynamoDB calls to go out
onto the public endpoint also in April
we introduced the DynamoDB accelerator
or Dax that allows you to put a right
through cash in front of DynamoDB but
keep using the same API s that you use
today this can significantly speed up
read operations and reduce costs on the
throughput capacity that DynamoDB needs
a big feature in June last year was auto
scaling rather than having to manage the
throughput requirements on each DynamoDB
table you can now specify some limits
and let DynamoDB manage the rest in
November 2017 we announced global tables
this is an important feature as more
customers deploy their applications
across the globe and want to have a
single source of key application data in
one place at the same time we also
introduced backup and restore
even though DynamoDB stores its data in
three facilities some customers want a
protection against user errors such as
accidental deletes and removing a whole
table and this functionality meets that
requirement last but definitely not
least we introduced encryption at rest
in February this year for enterprises
and regulated industries such as
financial services this has been a big
request Amazon Neptune is a new fully
managed graph database from AWS
it's in preview at the moment but should
be generally available later this year
it's designed to be very fast enabling
you to query billions of relationships
with millisecond latency it also has the
same level of durability as Amazon
Aurora with six copies of your data
spread across three availabilities
Jones it's easy to create graph queries
with support for gremlin and sparkle
plus it supports Apache tinker pop and
RDF graph models while many customers
use relational databases to solve graph
based problems today there are
increasing demands from different
domains for more complex graph
processing as you can see on this slide
there are three different domains one
from a social newsfeed another for

one for fraud detection we also see
graph problems in more typical
industries such as route planning for
traffic management and logistics or
network route planner problems - the two
caching solutions offered by the
elastics the cache service our memcache
and Redis so let's take a look at each
engine memcache is an in-memory cache
with a multi-threaded architecture that
can consume multiple cores it doesn't
support any persistence model so you
have to design your application to deal
with cache fail at failures memcache
only allows the storing of string values
so for some users this can be a
deal-breaker it does scale well
horizontally by adding new nodes and
sharding the data across each node Redis
is a more advanced in-memory cache but
it is single threaded it supports read
replicas and in Version three Redis
added support for clustering to scale
out the persistence model allows you to
take snapshots and create new instances
or clusters from those snapshots or
atomic operations allow you to use it
for counters and other critical
operations there are also advanced data
types such as ordered sets that are
great for game leaderboards top article
lists and so on some customers even use
the pub/sub messaging features like a
queue and we do see most customers using
Redis these days
